item.title: Lockdown fear haunts consumers
item.description: Latest Westpac research shows consumer confidence has dropped, signalling fresh fears of a second COVID-19 wave that will batter and bruise an early economic recovery.

item.title: Bed found in car of alleged predator
item.description: Police allege a man set up a makeshift bed in the back of his car before driving to meet who he believed was a teenage girl for sex on the NSW north coast.

item.title: Field to become Eels’ supersub
item.description: From almost joining Leeds to becoming Parramatta’s future supersub in a matter of months, Jai Field’s journey from NRL limbo to consistent star is complete.

item.title: Last straw for plastics
item.description: Banning single-use plastics starting with straws, stirrers, cutlery and plates has moved closer with legislation before the Queensland Parliament.

item.title: Foul-mouthed campaign cops backlash
item.description: A tongue-in-cheek tourism campaign urging Melburnians to stop breaching lockdown laws and travelling into regional Victoria has gone viral.

item.title: National icon’s ritzy new digs
item.description: The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) will move 450 employees to ritzy new offices at the Aerotropolis development in western Sydney.

item.title: Queensland is just rubbing it in now
item.description: Crowds returning to Queensland’s major theme parks on Wednesday seemed unfazed about the growing threat of COVID-19 clusters plaguing southern states.

item.title: Only one option for virus: Premier
item.description: Suppressing the spread of coronavirus is “the only option” for NSW, Premier Gladys Berejiklian says, claiming it is “unrealistic” to consider we could eliminate the virus from the state.

item.title: Raiders’ trump card to keep Cotric
item.description: Canterbury have upped their offer to Canberra winger Nick Cotric in a bid to lure him away from the nation’s capital, but the Raiders have an ace up their sleeve to secure the representative flyer.

item.title: Bosses ripping off workers face jail
item.description: One in four Queenslanders are missing out on part of their wage, prompting a landmark push to criminalise wage theft amid the global recession caused by COVID-19.
